For base rate information, please see previous results here: [2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Ivorian_presidential_election), [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Ivorian_presidential_election), and [2010](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Ivorian_presidential_election).

The incumbent, 83‑year‑old President Alassane Dramane Ouattara (RHDP), is running for a fourth consecutive term, a move that has sparked controversy and raised questions about constitutional limits. The electorate consists of 8.7 million registered voters (June 2025), all Ivorian nationals aged 18 or older who enjoy their civil and political rights, as defined in Article 55 of the 2016 Constitution. The election follows a two‑round, single‑member, majority‑vote system: a candidate must secure an absolute majority of valid votes to win outright; otherwise a runoff between the top two candidates is held fifteen days after the first‑round results are announced. Security concerns include jihadist activity and porous borders with Burkina Faso, which could destabilise the election.

Historically, no Ivorian presidential election has resulted in a peaceful alternation of power since 1995.
